Dear Elliott

Your general question re the use of casting tecniques for the=
 
production of tsuba, although probably asked in all innocence, opens a 
w=
hole 'can of worms'.

There is no doubt that casting was accepted as a skil=
led form of 
metalworking and was used to produce cast bronze vessels and m=
irrors, 
and iron kettles.  Indeed, a cast kagami is one of  the Three Sacr=
ed 
Regalia of Japan.  Kagami-shi tsuba, supposedly made in the pre-Edo 
pe=
riod by mirror makers, may also be of extremely high quality and it 
is not=
 illogical to suppose that many soft-metal tsuba may have 
initially been c=
ast.

But the casting of iron tsuba is, for some reason, very frowned upon =
by 
collectors.  I am personally convinced that the vast majority of Namban=
 
tsuba are cast and the poor quality of many of these makes this very 
eas=
y to detect with the use, simply, of a bright light and x30 
magnification.=
  The ease with which casting can be identified clearly 
depends upon the a=
mount of hand finishing which was utilised afterwards.

Many people will ju=
stify the casting of Manban tsuba as being expected 
because of their poor =
quality, but I believe that casting may have been 
used far more generally =
than is accepted.  It should be a simple matter 
to confirm this, but such =
examinations would need to be carried out on 
tsuba of accepted high qualit=
y in order to avoid the a priori excuse 
of 'poor quality'.

White cast iro=
n is not a suitable metal for casting, but the 
carburisation of grey cast =
iron to produce  a malleable cast iron, 
which is ideal for casting small a=
rtefacts such as tsuba, is a process 
that has been known in Japan for seve=
ral hundred years.

As to whether the tsuba illustrated in your photo album=
 is cast or not, 
I would hesitate to offer a firm opinion without a hands-=
on 
examination.  But my first impression is the absence of any clean, 
sha=
rp chisel-work - I have my suspicions!

Regards, John L.
